message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a disorder of glycogen storage. Among the options, only glycogen debrancher deficiency presents with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and elevated urine ketone bodies. Acid alpha-glucosidase deficiency presents with cardiomyopathy, and glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency presents with hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly. Glucocerebrosidase deficiency presents with hepatosplenomegaly, but does not cause hypotonia or wasting of skeletal muscles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory tests suggest a glycogen storage disease such as Pompe disease. Among the options, only Glycogen debrancher enzyme is involved in glycogen metabolism and deficiency can cause Pompe disease. Acid alpha-glucosidase deficiency causes another glycogen storage disease, Pompe disease. Glucose-6-phosphatase is involved in glucose metabolism and deficiency can cause Von Gierke's disease. Glucocerebrosidase deficiency causes Gaucher's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of poor feeding, irritability, hypotonia, and wasting of skeletal muscles suggest a glycogen storage disease. Among the options, only Glycogen debrancher enzyme deficiency causes these symptoms. Acid alpha-glucosidase deficiency causes Pompe disease, which presents with cardiomyopathy and respiratory distress. Glucose-6-phosphatase and Glucocerebrosidase deficiencies cause Von Gierke disease and Gaucher disease, respectively, both of which do not present with hypotonia and wasting of skeletal muscles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of glycogen storage disease, and among the options, only glycogen debrancher deficiency can cause hypotonia and wasting of skeletal muscles, hepatomegaly, and elevated urine ketones. Acid alpha-glucosidase deficiency causes Pompe disease, which affects cardiac and respiratory muscles. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes Von Gierke disease, which affects glucose homeostasis. Glucocerebrosidase deficiency causes Gaucher disease, which affects the lipid metabolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a glycogen storage disease. Among the options, only glycogen debrancher deficiency presents with hypotonia and wasting of skeletal muscles, hepatomegaly, and elevated urine ketone bodies. Acid alpha-glucosidase deficiency presents with cardiomegaly and Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency presents with fasting hypoglycemia. Glucocerebrosidase deficiency presents with hepatosplenomegaly and neurological symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest glycogen storage disease, and among the options, the most likely enzyme deficiency is glycogen debrancher. Acid alpha-glucosidase deficiency causes Pompe disease, which has a different clinical presentation. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes Von Gierke’s disease, which usually presents earlier in life. Glucocerebrosidase deficiency causes Gaucher's disease, which has different symptoms and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest a metabolic disorder related to glycogenolysis or glycogen metabolism. Among the options, glyogen debrancher deficiency would present with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive. Acid alpha-glucosidase deficiency causes Pompe disease, which presents with cardiomyopathy and respiratory muscle weakness. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes glycogen storage disease type I, which presents with fasting hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis. Glucocerebrosidase deficiency causes Gaucher disease, which presents with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and cytopenia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest glycogen storage disease, and among the options, only glycogen debrancher deficiency leads to hypotonia, muscle wasting, and elevated urine ketone bodies. Acid alpha-glucosidase deficiency leads to Pompe disease, which presents with cardiomegaly and respiratory distress. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency leads to Von Gierke disease, which presents with hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly. Glucocerebrosidase deficiency leads to Gaucher disease, which presents with hepatosplenomegaly and anemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a glycogen storage disease. Hypotonia and wasting of skeletal muscles suggest muscle involvement, and hepatomegaly suggests liver involvement. Among the options, the most likely enzyme deficiency is glycogen debrancher.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings indicate a glycogen storage disease. Among the options, only glycogen debrancher deficiency will cause hepatomegaly and hypotonia. Acid alpha-glucosidase deficiency will lead to Pompe disease, which shows cardiomegaly. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency will cause Von Gierke disease, which shows hypoglycemia and metabolic acidosis. Glucocerebrosidase deficiency will result in Gaucher disease, which shows neurologic manifestations and bone fractures.
